original: Roll Tables
Monster Traits
Aboleth Schemes
The Aboleth Seeks To …
Accomplish incomprehensible plans that lead it to act in seemingly random ways.
Learn more of the world by kidnapping people and consuming their minds.
Manipulate innocents into worshiping it as a god by using its telepathy from hiding.
Open a gate to the distant past or future, releasing an invasion from another time.
Rouse a dragon turtle, a kraken, or another sea monster to flood a coastal city.
Trick treasure hunters into recovering relics from its long-fallen empire.
Air Elemental Compositions
The Air Elemental’s Body Features …
Cumulus or cirrus clouds.
A mixture of vibrantly colored gases.
A pungent, sour-looking miasma
Shifting cloud clusters that resemble animals and simple shapes.
Sinister features obscured in a misty mass.
Swirling storm clouds.
Animated Object Catalysts
The Object Was Animated By …
A Celestial or Fiend using the object to protect or torment a mortal.
A combination of magic and technology, such as alchemy or alien science.
The essence of someone transformed by a supernatural trickster.
Fey as part of their games or wiles.
A magic-user in need of a guardian or servant.
Happenstance, with the item gaining a semblance of life after a hundred years of use.
The song of a magical instrument.
A spirit possessing the object.
Wild magic, a spell that went awry, or a chaotic Artifact.
The will of a powerful psychic being.
Ankheg Tunnel Discoveries
Inside the Ankheg Tunnel Is …
Another tunnel (either natural or of worked stone) that extends into the Underdark.
A buried ruin or grave exposed by the tunnel.
A cluster of 1d4 fresh ankheg eggs that can be broken and used as vials of Acid.
A dead ankheg and evidence of a deadlier subterranean predator.
A piece of ankheg carapace usable as a Shield.
A pouch with 2d6 GP near a puddle of acid.
A stray farm or woodland animal.
A viciously mauled scarecrow.
Arch-hag Anathemas
The Arch-hag’s Weakness Is …
The bones of the arch-hag’s first love.
A devil’s tear.
An egg with a miniature castle inside.
A flower that blooms only when time stops.
A gift from the hag’s twin.
The multiverse’s worst pun.
One of the hag’s missing teeth.
Snow from the top of Mount Celestia.
A star pulled from the sky.
A thread from the Lady of Pain’s robes.
Assassin Modus Operandi
The Assassin Is Infamous For …
Arranging their victims in artful tableaux.
Hiding within large objects, such as suits of armor or hollow furnishings.
Leaving behind a signature item, such as a calling card, flower, seashell, or tooth.
Posing as celebrities, holy people, or servants.
Taking trophies from their victims.
Using poison with a distinctive color or smell.
Bandit Motivations
The Bandit …
Fights only oppressors.
Is an ex-soldier who was discarded by their nation and now takes what they were promised.
Is in a gang that views nonmembers as foes.
Hesitantly serves a villainous leader.
Secretly works for a government or a regional ruler to sow chaos.
Takes what they need to survive.
Banshee Sorrows
Torment Compels the Banshee To …
Appear prior to a family member’s death.
Haunt the site where it was executed.
Lament a lost love and haunt their grave.
Presage a disaster or tragedy.
Seek the return of a stolen treasure.
Slay those more beautiful than it was in life.
Black Pudding Sources
The Black Pudding Formed From …
An ancient black dragon’s acidic saliva.
The blood or extreme emotions of a foul deity.
Cosmic entropy or ruinous planar forces.
A curse that transformed a forgotten tyrant.
Forbidden or industrialized magic.
Necrotic material animated by aimless spirits.
Blight Seed Creature
Twig Blight
Needle Blight
Vine Blight
Blob of Annihilation Contents
The Blob Contains …
An Amulet of the Planes.
An Artifact of the DM’s choice.
The corpses of two gods who were entangled in battle when the blob consumed them.
A Cubic Gate.
A Deck of Many Things.
A magic key that opens a door in Sigil that no other key and no spell can open.
The preserved corpse of an empyrean.
The remains of half a kraken.
The skull of a death god.
A tarrasque that just died.
Bone Devil Objectives
The Bone Devil Seeks To …
Capture a soul that escaped the Nine Hells.
Convey a message or make an example of someone in the name of an archdevil.
Find someone who broke a deal with a devil.
Slay someone or steal something as part of its pact with a wicked magic-user.
Cambion Origins
The Cambion Gained Its Power After …
Being possessed by a fiendish being.
Being resurrected by an evil magic-user.
Lengthy exposure to a Lower Plane.
Making a bargain with a Fiend.
Suffering a god’s curse.
Taking part in fiendish rituals.
Chain Devil Masks
To a Viewer, the Chain Devil Looks Like …
The corpse of a loved one.
A disapproving deity.
A harsh instructor or superior.
The viewer at their lowest point in life.
Clay Golem Orders
The Clay Golem Follows Orders To …
Block the path of anyone who enters a site with a weapon drawn.
Defend any member of their creator’s family or community who is threatened in its sight.
Prevent any Fiend from crossing a bridge.
Remove any who enter its creator’s workshop.
Cult Symbols
The symbol is an alchemical sign
The symbol is an animal
The symbol is a celestial body
The symbol is a deity’s icon
The symbol is an element
The symbol is an eye
The symbol is a geometric shape
The symbol is a letter or number
The symbol is part of a monster
The symbol is a skull
Cult Symbols - Depictions
Depicted as A calendar or map
Depicted as A crest or as heraldry
Depicted as An elaborate diagram
Depicted as A metaphorical image
Depicted as A mystical being
Depicted as Part of an equation
Depicted as A repeating pattern
Depicted as A series of scratches
Depicted as A simple pictogram
Depicted as A weapon or tool
Cultist Agendas
The Cultist Strives To …
Bring about the end of a dominant order, an age, or the world.
Expand their faith though mind control or supernatural coercion.
Burn away the comfortable lies of reality, revealing forgotten or terrible truths.
Make global changes, like sinking the land or awakening volcanoes.
Remake life on a mass scale, altering other creatures’ bodies or spiritual beings.
Summon their deity or its herald, weapon, or realm into their world.
Death Dog Malady Symptoms
The Death Dog’s Malady Causes …
Marks from canine jaws to appear on the victim’s body, as if they were still being mauled.
The victim’s body to wither, as if constantly exposed to desert heat.
The victim to be distracted by distant howling or vague whispers only they can hear.
The victim’s flesh to rot like a corpse.
The victim to itch, as if they had fleas or sand beneath their skin.
Wicked symbols to gradually appear on and spread across the victim’s body.
Demonic Undertakings
The Demon Is Compelled To …
Break open a vault and steal what’s within.
Defile a place using blasphemous symbols and demonic gore.
Fetch or otherwise provide materials for a profane ritual.
Guard a site and slay anyone who comes near.
Hunt down a foe, destroying everything barring the demon’s path.
Intimidate someone into following orders.
Deva Messages
The Deva Tasks a Mortal with Delivering …
The corpse of a hero in need of redemption.
The cure for a plague in a distant land.
A holy coffer that must not be opened.
A magic weapon usable only by a true hero.
A seedling that wilts if exposed to anger.
Someone from another world with a prophesied purpose but no memory.
Doppelganger Deceptions
The Doppelganger Schemes To …
Cause chaos within the temple of a deity that cursed it to live without a true form.
Conceal evidence of a vast conspiracy.
Control a community through fear by posing as a legendary bogeyman.
Replace a noble to enjoy a decadent lifestyle.
Spy on wizards to learn how to complete its own botched magical creation.
Take an influential position, acting as a sleeper agent for a doppelganger invasion.
Dracolich Soul Gem Vessels
A Dracolich’s Soul Gem Is Hidden In …
Another dragon’s treasure hoard.
The body of a servant or an ancestor.
The core of a dracolich’s melted hoard.
A corrupted dragon egg.
A dragon horn a hero took as a trophy.
A nation’s royal or religious treasure.
A powerful magic item.
A source of magical wonders, such as a giant tree or mystical pool.
The vault of an archdevil, a wicked god, or another extraplanar villain.
The weapon that slew the dracolich.
Drider Metamorphoses
The Drider Gained Its Form As …
A blessing from a deity of assassins, dangerous wildernesses, or the Underdark.
A curse from a powerful hag, vengeful witch, or strange Artifact.
An experiment by an aboleth, a mind flayer, or another life-shaping magic-user.
A magical means of escaping disaster or some worse fate.
A mutation after exposure to chaotic planar energies or strange Underdark radiations.
A punishment from a spiteful god, like Lolth or the Queen of Air and Darkness.
Druid Traditions
The Druid Is …
An avenger who strikes against destructive civilizations and those who abuse nature.
A guide who aids travelers in navigating the realms of Beasts, Fey, or Plants.
A hermit who works alone to protect the lands, seas, or skies they call home.
A mender who travels the world healing natural, magical, or manufactured disasters.
Part of a loose organization that adheres to timeless rituals and guards natural secrets.
A warden who minds the underpinnings of reality and protects against extraplanar threats.
Dryad Sanctuaries
The Dryad Dwells in and Protects …
An acres-large clonal colony—a stand of identical, interconnected trees.
A fortresslike tree, like a baobab or sequoia.
A living lock—a plant that seals evil below or blocks the path to a dungeon.
A lonely tree that stands atop a windswept mountain or amid a petrified forest.
A plant with magic fruit or remarkable seeds.
A shambling mound or treant that the dryad lives in or around as a Fey symbiote.
Earth Elemental Compositions
The Earth Elemental’s Body Features …
Colorful mineral formations.
Cooled magma in melted heaps.
Grass, moss, or plant roots.
Heaps of peat or decaying matter.
Mounds of sand studded with shells.
Rubble or pieces of a ruined structure.
Striking striations or bands of color.
Veins of iron or other ore.
Elemental Alterations
The Elemental Cataclysm Leaves Behind A …
Dramatic increase or decrease in temperature.
Gigantic coral reef or fungal forest.
Never-ending storm or whirlpool.
Passage to the Underdark or portal to an Elemental Plane.
Primeval or previously extinct animal population.
Rapidly growing rainforest.
River where previously there was none.
Series of dramatic rock formations.
Empyrean Influences
The Empyrean Has Features That Are …
Balanced, naturalistic, or suggestive of watching eyes.
Colorful, shadowy, or fluid or that vary depending on the viewer.
Comforting and gentle or that remind viewers of pleasant memories.
Disconnected parts, visible thoughts, or errant shapes.
Machinelike, stoic, symmetrical, or suggestive of judgment.
Morbid, menacing, or monstrous or that embody the viewer’s fears.
Ettin Interactions
The Ettin’s Heads Are …
Amping up one another in preparation for a conflict or challenge.
Arguing over plans for battle, dinner, or how to spend the day.
Criticizing one another as they perform separate tasks.
Engaged in a staring contest.
Making polite small talk as if they were meeting for the first time.
Performatively ignoring one another.
Talking over an increasingly convoluted plot.
Trying to keep one another awake.
Fire Elemental Compositions
The Fire Elemental’s Body Features …
Colorful, superheated gases.
A column of diabolical or divine flame.
Crackling shapes that look like animals, fiends, skeletons, sprites, or other beings.
Flames that are predominantly white, blue, or a more unusual color.
The form of a calm or tormented humanoid.
Smoke that forms eerie shapes or symbols.
Soot that smells like cedar, cloves, incense, or burning meat.
Swirls of cinders and burning debris.
Flameskull Details
The Flameskull Features …
Arcane diagrams etched into it.
Flames like dramatic features, horns, or hair.
Fractured pieces that fly in unison.
An iron plate bolted over its mouth.
Lethal head trauma.
Mismatched animal teeth.
Flesh Golem Characteristics
The Flesh Golem Has …
Animal parts among its humanlike pieces.
A disguise of makeup and heavy clothing.
Missing parts and exposed insides.
Parts serving unintended roles, like a body composed of dozens of hands.
Perfect features accented by beautiful stitching.
Visible mechanisms, bellows, and engines.
Flumph Assistance
The Flumph Helps By …
Cooking a meal of Underdark delicacies.
Performing a psychic song or “smell poem.”
Recovering and nursing fallen adventurers.
Revealing the location of helpful magic items.
Serving as a guide to a foe’s hidden lair.
Sharing excessive encouragement and praise.
Flumph Colors and Emotions
* Rarely seen; potentially no human equivalent
Color: Blue, Dark Emotion: Sadness
Color: Blue, Light Emotion: Happiness
Color: Green Emotion: Curiositiy
Color: Magenta Emotion: Unknown*
Color: Orange Emotion: Confusion
Color: Pink Emotion: Amusement
Color: Purple Emotion: Fear
Color: Red Emotion: Anger
Color: Teal Emotion: Serenity
Color: Yellow Emotion: Excitement
Fomorian Warping
The Fomorian’s Hex Causes …
Colorful, wandering pustules.
Excessive sweating of rainbow-hued fluids.
Patches of wriggling hair.
Veins that bulge and lurch under the skin.

Gargoyle Camouflage
The Gargoyle Conceals Itself Amid …
Burls and bark on a giant tree.
Monuments in a graveyard or memorial.
Outcroppings on a cliff or rock formation
Reliefs on a sculpted gate or wall.
The petrified victims of a basilisk or medusa.
Rubble in a ruin or junkyard.
Statuary on a castle, mansion, or temple.
Stalactites or icicles on a cavern ceiling.
Gargoyle Sculptures
The Gargoyle Is Sculpted to Appear …
Cherubic with perpetually smiling features.
Crudely hewed or naturally formed.
Damaged or marred by mismatched pieces.
Dragon-like with polished stone scales.
Gothically fiendish with horns and a tail.
Useful, like an ornate podium or a pillar.
Gelatinous Cube Debris
Floating in the Gelatinous Cube Is A …
Chest or recently trapped mimic.
Collection of bubbles or rocks resembling eyes.
Key to a nearby door or coffer.
Remarkable weapon in need of repair.
Skeleton belonging to a famous adventurer.
Tablet bearing a mysterious message.
Gibbering Mouther Nascencies
The Gibbering Mouther Is …
Another creature warped by dangerous magic.
The autonomous appendage of a chaotic deity, Far Realm entity, or star-spawn horror.
The experiment of an aberrant manipulator.
Part of the life cycle of some other Aberration.
A shape-shifter that lost control of its powers.
Someone cursed by a cult or vengeful deity.
Gith Conflicts
The Characters Are …
Called on to deliver a message or mysterious parcel to or from Vlaakith the Lich Queen.
Encouraged by a disguised intellect devourer to seek out an elusive gith leader.
Entreated to aid githzerai fleeing the githyanki who destroyed their sanctuary.
Entrusted with renewing or disrupting the githyanki’s alliance with red dragons.
Invited to hunt illithids with githyanki.
Pressed to uncover a gith spy in a planar community or on a spelljamming ship.
Sent on a quest to discover the last known location of the hero Gith or Zerthimon.
Tasked with returning the blade of a fallen githyanki knight to the knight’s people.
Gladiator Theatrics
During a Competition, the Gladiator …
Dedicates their impending victory to a deity, ruler, beloved noble, or member of the crowd.
Dresses in a monster-themed mask and cape.
Judges whether their foe fights honorably.
Leads the crowd in a rousing theme song.
Seeks to claim a trophy from a foe.
Takes advice from the crowd, omens, or a pet.
Gorgon Command Keys
Gorgon Won’t Attack Those That …
Cast a particular spell in the gorgon’s presence.
Keep their back to the gorgon or otherwise act like they don’t see the monster.
Offer it a drink of blood, water, or wine.
Recite a specific rhyme or sing a certain song.
Say its creator’s name backward.
Wear a mask, perhaps in the shape of a bull or an animal meaningful to the gorgon’s creator.
Green Hag Bargains
A Green Hag Trades Its Knowledge For …
A bargainer’s memories of a loved one.
The cauldron of a rival hag.
A favor to be redeemed when the hag wishes.
A flower from a hidden Feywild garden.
A gift given freely by a yugoloth.
A vial filled with a ruler’s tears.
Grell Explorations
Grells Travel Because They Are …
Advanced viruses, each the clone of all other grell. They exist only to feed and spread.
The larvae of another creature and require electrically charged environs to reproduce.
Seeking to escape some catastrophe or terror lurking in the depths.
Supernaturally connected to ravenous alien beings and serve as their feeding appendages.
Vestiges of an ancient evil that will return if grells collectively consume enough creatures.
Without souls, but convinced they can attain souls by eating certain beings.
Griffon Tales
Legends Claim That Griffons …
Attack anything in the skies near their lairs.
Curse their killers. Those who slay a griffon face the enmity of all animals.
Lay eggs with remarkable healing properties.
Prefer the taste of horses over all other prey.
Serve the first creature they see after hatching.
Won’t attack those with royal blood.
Grimlock Tasks
The Grimlock Serves Mind Flayers By …
Carving caves to serve as illithid outposts.
Hiding the threat of mind flayers beneath fake, purposefully crude dwellings.
Pretending to be helpful and luring travelers into false senses of security.
Raiding surface communities and tempting other creatures to pursue it into illithid traps.
Guardian Naga Lore
The Guardian Naga Recalls …
The last words of an ancient sage or leader.
The location of a hidden city or continent.
A magic word, password, or riddle’s answer.
The names of all who have told it stories.
An otherwise forgotten ritual or spell.
Recipes using regional ingredients.
Stories of forgotten gods and local spirits.
The vulnerabilities of a legendary monster.
Helmed Horror Directives
The Helmed Horror Follows Commands To …
Carry its master’s palanquin through the air.
Defend a remarkable treasure or piece of armor by incorporating the item into its being.
Imitate a dead or imprisoned hero by using their armor and weapons.
Perform as a laborer or servant.
Serve in a legion formed from the armors of a land’s ancient defenders.
Stand sentry in a gallery of mundane armors.
Hippogriff Destination
The Hippogriff Is Traveling to A …
Low-hanging moon, star, or other solar body.
Magical garden on a floating island.
Mountaintop with a view of a giant geoglyph.
Nest full of hippogriff eggs atop a spire.
Portal to the Feywild or an Upper Plane.
Lost ruin hidden by clouds or fog.
Hobgoblin Strategies
The Hobgoblin Works To …
Build a vessel to carry hobgoblin armies to new conquests.
Capture monsters and train them to fight.
Collapse a region into the Underdark so riches can be sifted from the ruins.
Construct a giant machine to strip resources.
Convince devils, dragons, or hobgoblins from Acheron to invade an enemy land.
Help shortsighted merchants undermine a government or despoil the environment.
Homunculus Features
The Homunculus Has Features That Are …
Bat-like with tattered wings.
Made of soft metal and delicate gears.
Marked with its creator’s symbol.
Similar to those of a winged humanoid.
Sprouting flowers and leaves.
Suggestive of its creator’s appearance.
Underdeveloped and fleshy with beady eyes.
Woven and patchwork, like a well-loved toy.

Hydra Lairs
The Hydra Lurks Where It Does To …
Ensure none claim the weapon of a fallen hero.
Defend the home of a wise but sinister oracle.
Guard a magical herb that blooms once a year.
Protect a font of poison that pollutes a river.
Incubus Nightmares
The Incubus’s Victim Has Dreams Of …
An angry family member or authority figure.
Being chased through the wilderness.
Being devoured by animals or monsters.
Falling, drowning, or suffocating.
A ruinous public embarrassment.
A shadowy intruder or monstrous silhouette.
A traumatic past event.
A visitor with an eerie or enigmatic message.
Iron Golem Orders
The Iron Golem Follows Orders To …
Block a door that has never been opened, moving only when a prophecy is fulfilled.
Exhale poison gas whenever it can, pausing only when someone speaks a passphrase.
Pose as a statue until a community’s hour of greatest need.
Stand atop the resting place of a powerful magic item.
Jackalwere Tricks
The Jackalwere Tricks Travelers By …
Guiding them into wildernesses, then abandoning them.
Mapping a shortcut through a monster’s lair.
Putting them to sleep, then stealing mounts or supplies.
Sharing the location of hidden treasure, which turns out to be sunlight on sand or water.
Kraken Attacks
The Enraged Kraken …
Abducts the vessel of a leader or another important community member.
Attacks a community from below using flooded ruins, hidden aquifers, or sewers.
Breaks a lighthouse or seaside tower, carrying it and the occupants to a secret island.
Calls down lightning on any ship that enters its aquatic territory.
Carries ships to an inescapable sargassum.
Dams a river or cuts off a city’s sea access.
Devours all sea life near a fishing community, threatening it with ruin.
Masterminds an invasion from the sea by merfolk, sahuagin, or storm giants.

Kuo-toa Ritual Sites
The Kuo-toa Community Features …
An arena scattered with weapons made from crustacean shells.
A gallery of hibernating chuuls.
A garden of mussels and tide pool creatures that whisper secrets.
A hidden shrine with a patchwork depiction of a new kuo-toa deity.
The lavish chamber of an animal or monster said to be prophetic, lucky, or literate.
A pool filled with jellyfish, eels, or fish roe that glow in organized patterns.
A punishment chamber exposed to the light of the surface.
A towering statue of a kuo-toa deity.
Lamia Pacts
The Lamia Compels the Bargainer To …
Bring it a possession from a ruler or noble.
Create a map of a dungeon or ruin.
Escort it through a nearby community’s gate.
Place a strange idol in a specific site or home.
Remove a magic item’s curse, then return it.
Slay a monster and retrieve a specific organ.
Lich Spirit Jars
The Lich’s Spirit Jar Is …
A bottle or puzzle box inscribed with sigils.
A contract folded into a paper figure.
The first magic item the lich created.
A hollow figurine of a deity or monster.
An hourglass with its sands floating in stasis.
A locket or signet ring with a noble crest.
A rune-etched egg.
The skull of the lich’s mentor.
Mage Roles
The Mage Is …
An astronomer who draws magic from stars.
An author who writes about the occult.
A magical engineer who creates wonders.
An oracle who interprets omens.
A prodigy with a remarkable magical heritage.
A psion whose powers manifest as spells.
A scholar investigating ancient lore.
A soothsayer who advises rulers.
A war mage who aids soldiers in battle.
A witch who shares secret wisdom.
Manticore Negotiations
The Manticore Agrees To …
Attack a particular foe.
Create a distraction.
Give up a captive or corpse.
Let a group navigate its territory unharmed.
Let someone pretend to slay it in battle.
Scare or threaten someone.
Serve a creature as a steed until the sun sets.
Try to locate something from its vantage point in the sky.
Medusa Fates
The Medusa Was …
Born a medusa and lives unaware of whatever curse or circumstances afflicted its ancestor.
Created by a god and tasked with guarding a treasure or secret.
A cultist who made a fiendish bargain and enjoyed rewards that have since faded.
An explorer transformed and compelled to defend a cursed ruin.
A vain noble whose magical attempt to gain eternal beauty backfired.
The victim of a bite from a magical serpent or reptilian god in disguise.
Mezzoloth Payments
The Mezzoloth Agrees to Serve For …
Access to a planar portal.
Information valued by its true master.
A lair where it can bring others of its kind.
Magic weapons or armor.
The right to loot holy sites in places it conquers.
Souls, whether as larvae or captured spirits.
Mind Flayer Machinations
The Mind Flayer Colony Seeks To …
Blot out the sun so their Underdark-dwelling servants can invade the surface.
Create a new monstrous fusion between mind flayers and a legendary monster.
Forge a psionic network uniting illithid colonies.
Replace world leaders with intellect devourers.
Restore a vessel to travel through Wildspace.
Sacrifice the mental energy of a planet’s populace to take control of a githyanki bastion.
Minotaur Mazes
The Minotaur of Baphomet Lurks In …
A multilevel mine or sewer.
Multiple mazes connected by magic portals.
A poisonous swamp with labyrinthine paths.
The ruins of a buried palace or temple.
Modron Operations
The Modrons Work To …
Create a clockwork outpost to monitor the balance of obscure planar forces.
Ensure neither side gains the upper hand in a conflict between good and evil.
Excavate a portal to another plane.
Find a lost contingent of modrons.
Reactivate a titanic but lost modron device.
Remove a forest, mountain, or city before the arrival of a modron procession.
Seal off a planar rift or wild magic zone.
Wage war with demons, slaadi, or chaotic Fey.
Mummy Lord Plots
The Mummy Lord Seeks To …
Open a portal to the past, when its power was at its height.
Perform a ritual that can be attempted only once every eight hundred years.
Reclaim and resurrect a loved one’s corpse.
Reconquer the lands that once composed its empire.
Recover the pieces of its lost heart.
Replace its descendant as the ruler of a realm.
Sacrifice a thousand souls to its god in return for true life.
Transform the people of an entire nation into Undead servants.
Mummy Resurrections
The Mummy Reanimates To …
Defend a holy site it was created to protect.
Obey the summons of a mummy lord.
Oppose an enemy who has returned to life.
Protect its descendants from an ancient threat.
Punish the progeny of those who cursed it.
Reclaim treasures robbed from its crypt.
Serve whoever speaks the prayer on its tomb.
Slay anyone who sets eyes on it.
Nightmare Riders
The Nightmare Carries …
The champion or messenger of an evil deity.
A group of joyriding imps or quasits.
An innocent soul trapped on the wild Fiend.
A lore-hunting mage, cultist, or lich.
A night hag herding larvae between planes.
A wicked cavalier, such as a death knight, an erinyes, an incubus, or a vampire.
Ochre Jelly Leftovers
After a Meal, the Ochre Jelly Leaves Behind …
A bone etched with a word or an eerie symbol.
Broken dragonborn or tiefling horns.
An ornate prosthetic limb.
The skeleton of an explorer’s pet (perhaps a small dog, monkey, or parrot).
A skull with gold teeth worth 1d4 GP.
A spotless suit of metal armor.
Oni Troubles
The Oni Torments People By …
Charming people to perform nasty tricks.
Claiming a bridge, gate, shrine, or trail and trying to eat anyone who comes near.
Luring other monsters to the settlement.
Playing drums that keep everyone awake.
Otyugh Lures
To Attract Potential Meals, the Otyugh …
Disguises its tentacles with garbage puppets.
Sings an enticing song in Otyugh.
Telepathically transmits a message like “Happy good stuff here!” or “Help now! I’m too delicious?”
Telepathically transmits an image of a large gemstone, crooked weapon, or soggy pastry.
Owlbear Den Features
An Owlbear Den Contains …
Evidence of previous occupants, like bandits, wolves, or dragons.
Heaps of regurgitated pellets studded with coins or other treasure.
A nest with 1d6 owlbear eggs.
Passages through the earth or hollow trees.

Bearing the gear of a hero the pegasus aided.
Offering magical fruit or holy spring water.
Singing a song in Celestial, Druidic, or Sylvan.
Wearing the garb of an ancient heroic order.

If a Peryton Collects Enough Hearts …
The hearts grant an evil wish.
It reverts to its original form.
A new peryton hatches from each heart.
A portal opens to the Lower Planes.
Petrified Basilisk Victims
A Basilisk Used Its Gaze to Petrify …
An adventurer with an ornate key hanging around their neck.
Animals like bats, bears, deer, or goats.
A climber clinging to a stalactite.
Itself using a large mirror or shiny surface.
A mimic disguised as a chest full of treasure.
A monster such as an umber hulk or a troglodyte.
Someone caught in a comic pose or making a regrettable face.
A victim now being used as a nest for insects or other vermin.

Planetar Quests
The Planetar Entreats a Mortal Hero To …
Convince a villain to meet with the angel.
Find a loved one a villain believes is dead.
Heal the loved one of an evil ruler.
Inspire the defenders of a besieged holy site.
Recover and destroy an evil Artifact.
Reveal the true name of a devil to banish it.
Poltergeist Activities
To Torment the Living, the Poltergeist …
Keeps returning a discarded item.
Leaves footprints on vertical surfaces.
Makes noises like someone trapped in a wall.
Organizes a pack’s contents across the floor.
Playfully puppets a corpse or doll.
Removes bedding while someone sleeps.
Sticks knives or weapons in the ceiling.
Uncannily stacks books, furniture, or utensils.
Priest Roles
The Priest Is …
An ascetic who keeps wicked spirits at bay.
An elder who speaks for the dead.
An exorcist who hunts wicked spirits.
A follower of a god no one has heard of.
A mediator and teacher of traditional ways.
A philosopher devoted to a concept, multiversal view, or plane of existence.
The reincarnation of an ancient faith leader.
A ritualist who uses tinctures and performances to access the divine.
A shaman whose medicines ease many ills.
A zealot who wages war for a divine cause.
Pseudodragon Treats
The Pseudodragon Wants …
Flamboyant accessories it can wear.
Mementos from a lost friend or master.
Outlandish delicacies—like axe beak-egg omelets or mammoth-milk cheese.
The possessions of a sibling, rival, or master.
Shiny gifts, from gems to abalone shells.
Soft bedding and stuffed toys.
A specific cook’s signature dessert.
Time-consuming beauty treatments.
To hear a bedtime story or favorite song.
Trophies and important-sounding titles.
Roc Nest Remnants
The Roc’s Nest Holds …
The burial litter of a lost hero.
A caravan wagon full of trade goods.
A live elephant.
[[/r 1d4#Eggs]]{1d4 eggs} larger than adult humans
Someone marooned in the nest.
A statue of a knight riding a rearing steed.
Roper Hazards
The Roper Drags Prey Through …
Areas that trigger traps.
Caverns filled with smoke or gas.

Scarecrow Frames
The Scarecrow Is Made From …
Animal furs, bones, horns, and claws.
Beehives or wasp nests over a wicker frame.
A carved pumpkin atop a body of thick vines.
Nets, flotsam, grapnels, and fishing tackle.
Oversize stuffed animal or mannequin parts.
Rusty armor and torture devices.
A sackcloth head atop straw-stuffed clothes.
Wedding clothes that were never worn.
Sea Hag Disguises
The Sea Hag Takes the Form of A …
Captive and claims nearby villagers bound them and left them to drown.
Castaway and shares a cursed item’s location with would-be rescuers.
Healer and passes off poisons as medicine.
Panic-spreading prophesier of doom.
Ship captain and delivers passengers to the hag’s pet sea monster.
Wounded sailor and claims their ship was destroyed by merfolk or other peaceful people.
Shadow Shapes
The Shadow Appears As …
A distorted stalker that lurks in the woods.
A fiend that dwells near a wicked ritual site.
Grasping hands that haunt a miser’s home.
A grim storybook character that follows those who speak its name.
Its target, acting in eerie pantomime.
An ominous priest that haunts a defiled site.
Shambling Mound Cultivation
The Shambling Mound Is …
Covered in vibrant alien or Feywild blooms.
Hauling a rune-etched menhir in its torso.
Infested with vermin or fungi.
Made up of knotty vines entangling skeletons.
Mutated and leaking glowing pollution.
The remains of an ancient tree or a treant.
Skeleton Pantomimes
Left to Its Own Devices, the Skeleton …
Delivers meal salvers or ages-old correspondence to the crypt of its dead master.
Endlessly trains in battle with other skeletons, despite being hacked to animate splinters.
Mimics ways it entertained itself in life, such as acting, dancing, or reading.
Performs a familiar task, such as cleaning, cooking, mining, or praying.
Repeats its final moments of life.
Stands guard at the post it protected in life.
Specter Haunts
The Specter Lurks Near …
A community afflicted by curses, grudges, plagues, or tragedies.
An evil Artifact or a deadly magical device.
The place where a villain died or is buried.
The lair of a Fiend or an Undead.
A portal to the Lower Planes, Negative Plane, or Shadowfell.
The sanctuary of a necromancer or death cult.
A secluded monument binding wicked souls.
The site of a disaster or mass death.
Spined Devil Intelligence
The Spined Devil Covets Information About …
Artifacts, their locations, and their owners.
Betrayals by infernal allies or other devils.
Crimes or deceptions by influential leaders.
Prophecies or secrets hidden by gods.
The identities of incognito individuals.
The movements of extraplanar armies.
Spirit Naga Grievances
The Spirit Naga Believes …
A character is to blame for its recent failures.
It has been evicted from its rightful home.
Locals have reneged on an age-old bargain.
Other creatures are mocking it.
A rival is spying on it.
Someone’s treasure rightfully belongs to it.
Spy Personas
The Spy Disguises Themself As …
A bard or traveling performer.
A captive or servant of a monster or villain.
A dignitary or traveler from a distant land.
A visitor from a different time or world.
Stirge Roosts
Between Hunts, the Stirge Lurks In …
The attic or furniture of a ruined building.
A cave or narrow crevice.
A hollow tree or thicket.
The remains of a gigantic, dead creature.
Stone Golem Orders
The Stone Golem Follows Orders To …
Allow only those wearing ritual garb to pass.
Cast Slow on and aid in apprehending anyone who touches a city’s prized relic.
Destroy a dam or bridge at the command of one bearing a ruler’s medallion of office.
Obey whoever places a missing crest in its chest, then deactivate for a year.
Reveal a hidden passage to those who recite a leader’s final words.
Watch for and do battle with the type of monster that slew the hero it resembles.
Succubus Temptations
The Succubus Manipulates Its Target By …
Adopting the form of a lost loved one.
Charming someone close to its target.
Isolating them from their loved ones.
Manipulating events to bring surprise fortune.
Posing as a flattering underling.
Taking the form of one in need of protection.
Tarrasque Evidence
Amid Destruction, the Tarrasque Leaves …
Evidence of a magic spell reflected back on its caster, like Ice Knife or Melf’s Acid Arrow .
Massive footprints or claw marks.
A shattered mountain or diverted river.
A russet scale the size of a knight’s shield.
Treant Secrets
The Treant Is …
Blessed by a god and grows magic fruit.
Growing atop the entrance to a dungeon or portal to the Feywild.
Home to a community of pixies or sprites.
The last lore keeper of lost druidic knowledge.
Rooted on a hero’s burial mound and animates trees that look like questing knights.
Scarred by a fire and holds the bones of the arsonist who started it in a hollow.
Ultroloth Conspiracies
The Ultroloth Schemes To …
Convince cultists their god has forsaken them.
Destabilize a nation and rule the chaos.
Incite a calamity and hold a world hostage.
Provoke hostilities between immortal armies and sell magic weapons to both sides.
Steal an invention and slay all who know of it.
Unleash fiendish hordes on a foe’s homeland.
Uncontrolled Invisible Stalkers
The Invisible Stalker Is …
The breath of an infamous god or monster.
A guardian of a hidden portal or magical site.
The lingering violent thoughts of someone killed in a great battle.
A manifestation of uncontrolled magic.
A servant of an evil elemental ruler such as Yan-C-Bin (the Elemental Prince of Evil Air).
Unable to complete its duty and tries to create circumstances allowing it to fulfill its task.
Vampire Resting Places
The Vampire’s Resting Place Is …
Among the roots of a dead tree.
At the bottom of a stagnant pool.
A coffin filled with grave dirt.
A large pot full of blood or vinegar.
A space accessible only by shape-shifting.
Within a statue or suit of armor.
Warrior Roles
The Warrior Is …
A bodyguard who protects a noble.
A cavalry officer with an unusual steed.
A crusader who fights for a divine cause.
A duelist who claims to be unbeatable.
A gate guard who asks nonsensical questions.
A grizzled veteran who trains new recruits.
A hunter skilled at slaying specific monsters.
A retired general who is weary of battle.
A volunteer with a homemade weapon.
A young mercenary trying to prove their skill.
Water Elemental Compositions
The Water Elemental’s Body Features …
Chilling or near-boiling temperatures.
Energetic effervescence.
Muddy, polluted, or crystal-clear water.
Seaweed, tiny fish, or other sea life.
Weretiger Wards
The Weretiger Protects A …
Legendary weapon or symbol of rulership.
Proving ground for prophesied heroes.
Rare species of magical plant or animal.
Sacred fountain with magical waters.
Wight Motives
The Wight Returned from the Dead To …
Challenge anyone who passes near its grave on a certain cursed night.
Conquer the land it believes it should rule.
Continue the crimes it was executed for.
Follow the foul master it served in life.
Honor an oath it left unfulfilled in life.
Obey the cult or deity that gave it unlife.
Prove it was the greatest warrior to ever live.
Seek its stolen heart or other treasure.
Will-o’-Wisp Ambushes
The Will-o’-Wisp Tempts Victims Into …
An abandoned structure ready to collapse.
An ambush by hungry ghouls or vampires.
A dreaded ruin that curses those who enter.
The lair of a predator, like a bear or wyvern.

The blasphemous magic of a cursed location.
The exorcised evil of a redeemed villain.
A legendary villain who returns once a century.
Locals’ fear of a superstition or legend.
The memory of a tragedy.
A profane idea or foul piece of lore.
The torment of one or more suffering souls.
The viciousness of a profane Artifact.
The vile dreams of a slumbering god.
The voracity of a life-hungry realm, such as the Shadowfell or Negative Plane.

Adamantine or mithral.
Coins minted by a long-dead empire.
Fossils or petrified wood.
A gem that’s part of a magic item.
The keystone of a great arch or bridge.

The stone crowning a mountain peak.

Bargaining parts of its soul to a pantheon of serpentine demigods.
A curse laid on its people in the distant past.
The dream-venom of Merrshaulk, a slumbering snake god.
Experiments by spirit nagas or other yuan-ti.

Enlist monsters as allies or beasts of war.
